your **post** or **comment** was removed for violating the rule “no medical & legal advice” reddit and the internet in general are not the best places to get or give medical or legal advice do not ask about symptoms post pictures of symptoms injury ask if you should seek a medical professional make an appointment visit an emergency department or acute urgent care center etc do not give medical advice home remedies suggest medications or suggest medical procedures to people seeking support for a medical diagnosis do not ask if something is legal illegal whether you should call the police engage an attorney or call report to child welfare agencies always consult a professional in these matters consider looking up local helplines in your area like ask a nurse or legal aid offices for questions about this moderation reach out [through modmail] moderators rely on the community to help illuminate posts and comments that do not meet r parenting standards – please report posts and comments you feel don’t contribute to the spirit of the community **your content may have been automatically removed through auto moderation or manually removed by a human moderator it may have been removed as a direct result of your rule violation or simply as part of a larger sweep of content that no longer contributed to the original topic **

all video games are somewhat addictive basically if they don't make you want to play it then they are not good games however puzzle and online games that are so common in mobile phones are usually a lot more addictive than most of the traditional video games from pc and consoles the social aspect forums streaming youtube only makes things worse my kids are still young so we'll see what happens in the future but for now we set up a policy where the only games they can play are console games hour a day times a week works for us but obviously it's different for each family i thought that they would have better memories of their childhood remembering when they used to play together mario kart or super smash bros than silly repetitive game # on a phone or a tablet by themselves pcs are for homework only a total ban of video games might be excessive but a total ban of something they are not ready to handle as in this case is completely appropriate even most adults can't properly handle how addictive mobile phones can be even without ever playing a single video game in them that's why phones come with settings to limit yourself on the time you spend using a certain application

daughter bought robux on my card for a second time not sure if my punishment is enough i've never posted here but i'm looking for some advice ideas my year old daughter loves roblox and she used to get screentime to call her friends and play together on her ipad over a week ago i noticed i got locked out of my amazon account and when i checked my email to get back into my account there were hundreds of dollars of suspicious charges the customer service rep confirmed it was roblox and it took over an hour over the phone but luckily they refunded it all they said it can be tricky to get refunded my daughter had her ipad taken away and wasn't allowed to talk to friends for a week i was under the impression that her ipad wasn't in kid mode and that must've allowed the purchases because in four years she had never bought anything before today after a talk and promises to never ever do that again i gave her the ipad back with kid mode on sure enough though i was going through my email and i found a ton of purchases again only a couple of hours after she got it back i was furious we had another long conversation about how wrong it is to steal from mom and how disappointed and disgusted i am and i said that her ipad is gone indefinitely i'll have to call amazon in the morning again to hopefully get that money back too because i'm broke long story short i quit my job to care for my terminally ill mother and i haven't found anything remote yet so i only have a couple hundred dollars in my checking as it is i'm fucked if amazon doesn't refund me she was told there would again be no friends no tv or anything fun tomorrow especially just working with me outside or doing cleaning around the house i feel like i don't know how to make it sink in or what to say to make her understand i never would've dreamed of doing this to my parents and she looked ashamed but i feel like i don't know if she gets it hell i question if she's just so short sighted that she didn't think there'd be any consequences or if she just doesn't respect me because she ignored everything we had just talked about is there something i'm missing to make her understand i tried to explain that when she buys things online with my card it's the same thing as reaching in my wallet and pulling out money i'm just not sure if it's not a serious enough consequence or if i need to focus more on how i discuss it with her to make her realize her wrongs i worry that she's not afraid of consequences or doesn't care enough about them which tells me that maybe i'm missing the mark and not getting through to her is there something else i should add for a punishment is there more i should add to the discussion i was flustered so i didn't ask about why she did it just focused on how it felt to have her do that to me for a second time honestly i don't know if the 'why' matters i'm just hurt afraid i can't get that money back and feeling like i don't have my kid's respect tl;dr my daughter made in game purchases on my card was punished and immediately did it a second time when she got it back not sure if my punishments or discussions are enough to make her change her behavior and understand how terrible stealing is how can i help her understand how serious this is and be sure she respects me edit thank you everyone for the responses and suggestions roblox is gone for sure i will continue my discussion with money and i will have her earn the money back i will say that after the first time i changed up the passwords made sure that she couldn't get into my account without a second different password and i had assumed that without my adult account she couldn't make any purchases because the older ipad she had would always block purchases unless i logged in i've gone through the game with her before and there are a lot of ads and in game purchases but she pointed them out to me and said you have to buy those so don't click on them so naively i thought she knew to never buy anything as this was long before the problem began i will talk to her more about the 'why' again because i know she likes to video chat her friends and she might have felt pressured to buy that

obviously stealing is wrong but i feel like i'm missing something why did you get locked out of your *amazon* account roblox isn't connected to amazon in any way amazon only sells robux gift cards presumably your daughter had to log into your amazon account purchase robux digital gift cards access your amazon digital items page or your email account copy the gift code use a web browser to access the roblox redeem codes website log into her roblox account and paste the gift codes none of that is particularly challenging for an adult and kids are capable of figuring a lot of things out i'm not saying your kid was extra devious for doing that but i think you might have a fundamental misunderstanding about how kid mode works and what actually happened this isn't something that was done through the roblox app apple has a lot of options for restricting access maybe you are staying signed in to amazon with your card info saved or only restricting certain apps you don't even understand what she did so it's going to be hard for you to explain it to her i know that tech is confusing but you really need to get your own head around what is happening before doling out punishment if you don't understand it how can you expect her to understand it it also sounds likely that you might be assuming everything is fine because of whatever kid mode you're turning on and not really monitoring her tech use at all most importantly you need to understand the tech your kid uses well enough to prevent this from happening again and to protect your kid in the worst case scenario that she's talking to someone online who is manipulating her for some e gift card scam if tech isn't your thing try to find a trusted friend you could ask to explain what happened and show you how to protect your accounts and kid as you yourself come to understand what is happening you may find you will be able to explain to your daughter what she is not allowed to do and understand what punishment is necessary or if this was all a big misunderstanding

she's spending too much time on her ipad instead of going outside playing with friends or even watching tv so you forbade her from doing anything she likes aside from playing on the ipad hmm this is a technological problem hundreds of phd level people have spent a decade tuning the ipad and roblox and amazon to make it addictive and make people especially kids buy digital stuff which costs them basically nothing to provide so has a nearly profit margin for them that's what you're fighting your daughter is eight years old she cannot possibly resist this if anyone should be punished here it's apple and amazon and robolox seriously don't bother punishing her just make it impossible for her to make charges using the ipad there should be nothing she can poke on the ipad to cause a charge the apple account and the amazon account that the ipad is logged into should not have credit cards on file period make separate accounts if necessary also its use should be supervised and limited in duration let her use it when you're in a position to keep an eye maybe at the kitchen table while you're doing stuff in the kitchen

it’s a dopamine response it’s like pulling the lever at a casino or checking the coin return in a machine she literally has to fight her brain about doing it now that she’s been exposed to it it’s your job as a parent to lock that stuff down you cannot operate on “good faith” alone with a kid this age you’re saying ipad and not just tablet so do the following if children in your family sharing group have their own devices use [ask to buy] to screen and approve their purchase requests [require a password] for every purchase not something guessable a random combination of symbols letters and numbers do not save it on the device you can also turn off in app purchases entirely using screen time on your own device or a child's device to use screen time settings > screen time then tap turn on screen time tap continue then choose this is my [device] or this is my child's [device] to prevent another family member from changing your settings as the parent on your device tap use screen time passcode to create a passcode then re enter the passcode to confirm in ios and later after you confirm your passcode you'll be asked to enter your apple id and password this can be used to reset your screen time passcode if you forget it use new and different codes and passwords on your child's device follow the prompts until you get to parent passcode and enter a passcode re enter the passcode to confirm in ios and later after you confirm your passcode you'll be asked to enter your apple id and password tap content & privacy restrictions if asked enter your passcode then turn on content & privacy tap itunes & app store purchases tap in app purchases and select “don’t allow” finally you can also go to settings > screen time > content & privacy restrictions and tap allowed apps then deselect itunes store and books deselect amazon and any other apps or websites that are problematic you should also [set the parental controls for amazon ] again new and different passwords you should also disable one click payments go to manage default address & one click settings > click here to change default address > click edit next to the payment method you might also consider opening a chime account and making it the default payment method this way if she slips through it gets declined do all of this

please tell me you didn’t tell your daughter your disgusted with her you can be upset but it should be at yourself the failure here is not putting the parent settings on the ipad those games are designed to get people to engage in micro transactions they make it really easy ask you constantly and highly rewarding or maybe she just and really doesn’t understand that clicking that button means you’re spending real money im confused at your decision to quit your job it sounds like you’re risking your daughter’s future here for your mother’s sake isn’t there other care available like hospice

taking the ipad away is appropriate before you give it back if you give it back you should definitely unsave all of your bank card info or even cancel the cards and getting new ones sent if you don't know how to get amazon and apps to forget the info make it impossible for her to buy anything with your cards without getting you to come make the purchase yourself i think you definitely need to understand the why if you don't know why she did it you won't know how to explain why she shouldn't and mustn't again and you might miss important steps you need to take beyond locking down your bank accounts just think through a few possible reasons is it peer pressure because she sees her friends doing it is it one friend convincing her it's worth it is it the game itself being too tempting does she not understand despite your explanation that it is real money and not play money does she understand that but not understand that hundreds of dollars is a lot each of those requires a different explanation and possible follow up steps like contacting other parents supervisingcertain friendships deleting the game itself and not allowing future games driven by in app purchases or involving her in budgeting decisions so she learns what you both need money for

honesty she is young and she might not grasp the concept of bills and budgets not seeing money or a credit card or check might not make it click in her head that it’s money because it’s not a tangible thing for the well being of your child’s mental health and development i would stray away from punishing her with food as some have stated i would also not throw your financial status in her face explaining frugality is one thing saying now we can’t pay bills because of you is another being mindful of your lessons and how they could be interpreted by a young undeveloped mind will help some good framework for lesson learning can be “think of good deeds you can do to earn privileges” this can be behaving well using polite manners with everyone quietly doing an activity helping with housework helping put away groceries etc explaining why she cannot have the ipad until a time you deem appropriate age appropriate homework for summer enrichment maybe money or math oriented to allow for stimulation for understanding work on figuring out how it was able to happen and stop it from happening kid mode does not protect your passwords or saved payment methods so maybe that’s why is leading to it many apps allow apple pay amazon pay paypal etc you could absolutely sell the ipad for funds if necessary because clearly providing for your family is important also you could make it a password requirement for any game download and if it says in app purchases act accordingly i can see how frustrating and scary it is for you to have hundreds of dollars hanging in the balance remember it was likely not out of malice if you’re unsure of the logistics it’s likely your daughter doesn’t understand either good on you for looking for help and answers good luck

first i am so sorry to hear about your wife my advice would be to lock your card when you do not need it set a spending cap so anything over a certain amount declines unless you authorize it i get an email for these when i have a cap set or log out of amazon and make sure the password is not saved on any devices she uses also you could enable text notifications or email notifications on purchases pretty sure you can set it for a minimal amount to inform you too i do this with my cards i get a text shortly after a charge is made telling me how much and where it was spent you can then more immediately dispute any unauthorized charges last scenario would be to unlink amazon from your payment info a pain but she wouldn't be able to do it anymore as for punishment if she stole money from anyone else she would likely have had a cop talking to her you need to tell her this is something that could get her in big big trouble i would definitely make her work around the house more than her normal chores to pay you back age appropriate chores of course i'd also really consider selling the tablet since she is proving to you that she is not mature enough for one if you have any unnecessary items unused items you could try selling them but honestly that's hot or miss you should also sit her down and discuss what a budget is and how electronic payments and physical cash works you can list out what you make per month and your bills and how much and have it show what is left over then you can explain that x is how much you should have had for the budget but because she took without asking for permission that you only have z until next payday talking finances with kids can be beneficial since it helps teach money management if your handy with excel it makes it easy to show debt to income

so i've had this issue with my yr old take away all internet all of it even the school computer trust me they will understand we are going on months without her having any access including a smart tv cause guess what they can use that too they also know how to use spotify as a chat program she's been enrolled in adolescent medicine so she's getting medication currently to help with depression and is on a bunch of therapy wait lists she was catfishing adults on top of having been groomed all of this came from people she met in forrnite since taking that all away she is much happier now even more so that her depression is being addressed she's earned her switch back for single player only she doesn't know the internet password she now has a text and phone call only cell phone that we monitor sporadically but seriously don't be afraid to take that access and definitely get her into therapy since she's obviously suffered some sort of trauma it needs to be addressed

there's a lot of good comments here that highlight the importance of boundaries and educating your daughter a yr old is old enough to start learning financial responsibility i personally would recommend a prepaid debt card that she can use for these subscriptions using her own money that she's been able to save up or that she works for these can be reloaded when they run out which also gives you the ability to limit her on how much she can spend if there's no money on the card her subscriptions will automatically cancel and you xan take the opportunity to teach her how to cancel the subscription she pays for if a prepaid card feels like too much you can also manage subscriptions with gift cards that can only be used on specific apps she needs to be able to see how her money is being spent teaching her how to use a budget can also help her but this will only work if you follow through with establishing boundaries with grandma i'd also give her an electronics time out she abused phone privileges so she looses the phone for a set amount of time when you give it back make sure she understands why she lost the phone and what the consequence was and that it will be taken away for longer if it happens again if she values having a phone she will respect the boundaries i might recommend that if a phone is important for communication then if the problem persists after taking it away more than once then you xan downgrade her to a flip phone that only has minutes these were things my parents did in similar situations when i was her age and it made a huge difference you got this mama

welcome to my world man do my kids love roblox they also love watching videos of other people playing roblox roblox is fairly harmless some of the games do involve shooting but it's very low resolution and there's no blood it's like minecraft level graphics but if you don't approve of anything relating to guns just make sure to monitor what your daughter plays i've banned my kids from playing virtually all first person shooters but i find most roblox games even the shooters such that they are to be fine roblox has a ton of games that are user created so it's tough to really say what type of games there are because there are so many fortunately for my kids or unfortunately depending on who you ask i'm a fairly avid gamer so it's a lot easier for me to figure out which games are appropriate for children and which games aren't it's actually pretty hard for parents who aren't into gaming because of how games have exploded on the internet be careful with some of the roblox videos some are harmless but others aren't depending on your threshold for profanity crudeness some of the videos may not be appropriate for your child i've had to ban a few youtube channels from my kids because of that also consider that some youtube personalities yeah that's a thing just get used to it are very annoying and your child may pick up some of those annoying traits it's probably worth watching a few episodes to make sure that you're fine with the content

imo the minor obsession is typical for her age especially with games like roblox and minecraft as long as it is not interfering with daily life it shouldn't be a problem if she starts to choose the game over real life or as an avoidance tactic you may have concerns especially considering the social anxiety history in your family as far as interacting with others this is always going to be a risk with online games and apps this might be a good time for a brief conversation about internet safety and when she should bring something to you roblox does offer parental controls so you can choose certain restrictions including chat and content related controls for those under go into the game settings and you should be able to choose these options among others online features are now a part of nearly all games and it will likely only intensify as she gets older i highly recommend that she show you any game or app she starts using so you get familiar with the content you can use great resources like commonsensemedia org but user created content has the highest likelihood for slipping inappropriate content into games intended for younger users nothing beats watching her play or better yet playing it yourself

honestly your best resource to get info about particular games might be just to ask here on reddit enough of us are gamers that you're likely to get decent advice anything online with the ability to chat with other players runs some risk of exposing them to pretty awful people and pretty awful content this isn't to say you should disallow online games but you should establish ground rules for what's acceptable and what's not talking to people trying to get pictures or personal information is not ok anyone yelling racial slurs or screaming about ethnic groups political groups sexual identities and so forth should just be ignored i routinely report and ignore wannabe nazis and the like on the wwii themed first person shooter i like to play anyone advertising in game stuff for sale with your credit card or paypal account should probably be avoided once you get past that well some of my longest running friendships have started as people i first encountered in online games and chatrooms if you use caution and some common sense it's as rewarding as any other social setting

let me start off by saying roblox is full of kids but not only you need to talk to your daughter about a few things first off never give anyone too much information and **never** let anyone else know your password make sure you write passwords down accounts can have a lot of in game ”items” that your daughter probably worked hard for also warn her about scamming a lot of people trick others online to steal their items items can have value in real life don’t know if that’s the case in roblox i had an item stolen from me that i had worked hard for but in another game make sure to not take words personal and serious this happened to me but on social media i was about and someone called me a dickhead i cried and told my mom i learned from there that it’s normal and this tip is for you i am into gaming and got into it young here are a few tips take breaks this is very important and is very good to create a habit out of tell your daughter to get up while she’s playing and do some physical movements could be stretching or anything really while taking the breaks make sure to drink water staying hydrated as you know is very important and can be forgotten as time can be lost track of when playing don’t let your daughter have social medias maybe when she becomes old enough to actually have an account on most social medias i wouldn’t recommend getting social medias at all as they just affect you in negative ways and are addicting i can’t think of more right now my phone is almost dead i will go to sleep and respond to any of your questions tomorrow i might just be but i would call myself mature enough and experienced enough to know what i am talking about

there’s lots of good advice in this post and i’d like to add a couple to keep an eye for basic internet safety make sure she knows to keep her personal information to herself where she lives what school etc i personally tell my son not to share his age just that he is a kid with his online friends as well as passwords and be weary about sharing info that can potentially be used for password recovery favorite food color pets names favorite teacher etc as for your daughter keep her engaged in talking to you about what she does online ask her about what kinds of games she plays in roblox many are user created ask her about her friends she plays with ask her about her drawings you want to keep the dialog about her online life open so that she’s comfortable to talk to you should anything bad happen you’ll also want to keep an eye on her behavior being ‘obsessed’ with something her age isn’t uncommon boy bands were my vice around that age but if she suddenly becomes obsessed real life being sacrificed for online life or drops it suddenly while being moody and avoiding talking about it it might be a good idea to gently pry the best thing and the worst thing about the internet is that everyone uses it at the end of the day you don’t know who you’re talking to through the screen at the end of the day moderation caution and open dialog are always good there’s no need to restrict so long as everyone is comfortable and real life isn’t suffering there’s also no need to be paranoid but a little caution helps with peace of mind if nothing else and talking to your kids about the stuff they love does wonders for them even if it can be a bit tedious for us you and your daughter seem to be doing great keep it up

yeah roblox is harmless it's honestly a bit young for yos in fact kids need to roam around in unsupervised packs and that's just not something modern lifestyles allow for when you were a kid you got to wander or bike around the streets with your friends but that's been denied to their generation multiplayer gaming has stepped in to fill that gap it lets them practice a bunch of social skills that just aren't available via playdates or the schoolyard; it lets them be pack for want of a better word yeah the video obsession is normal projecting their socialization into that world makes it awfully compelling to watch and freeform games like roblox strongly facilitate storytelling in the medium as well a little common sense around online safety no personal details no meetups etc has the stranger danger angle covered of far more concern with gaming in general is kids getting exploited for micro transactions various games have in game items you pay real money for and the marketing and peer pressure to have the latest and greatest can be relentless no different from whatever collectibles or must have status symbols kids obsessed over in your day but in game ones can be really insidious i don't think it's unhealthy at all but you might do well to fence off certain times for other activities as it can be easy to spiral into it

my year old participated in online bullying and needs consequences last night i found out about a tiktok account that is targeting specific students at my daughter’s school the account describes students using discriminatory language and the kids comment guessing who the posts are about my daughter was targeted by name in one post i also saw she participated in comments on two other posts obviously bullying is unacceptable i took screenshots and sent them to her teacher and principal she was not supposed to have tiktok in the first place so i will be making her delete her account i’m also considering banning all social media including roblox i’m considering taking her phone away for a while but this is complicated by our custody agreement her father lives on the other side of the country and she is supposed to have a phone so they can talk at least three times a week she has never done anything like this in the past so i’m not sure how hard i need to be on her i don’t trust her to have any form of social media since she participated in bullying she also just recently got a private therapist so i will also be reaching out to them what are the best consequences i can give that make sense and will drive her to understand that i won’t tolerate bullying

i went through a similar situation with my year old boy and was absolutely floored by his behavior towards another kid in a group online bullying situation while he had other consequences apologizing had him read a kid friendly article on what bullying does to others… it’s tough to take away their phone completely one because we need to be able to get ahold of him because we’re both working parents and he’s active in sports and academics and two of how his school uses qr codes to provide access to almost everything each classes syllabus links to parent forms registration for clubs sports registration etc which is a whole other issue in itself anyway i blocked or deleted everything on his phone for two months like internet access can’t download any apps airdrop the whole nine yards basically i turned his phone into a “dumb phone” because he only had access to his camera for qr codes texting and calling i limited his contacts during certain hours through screen time on his apple phone and he couldn’t add contacts unless i approved them anyway looking back i’m glad i took it so seriously because then he had to take it his behavior seriously as well if that makes sense hope this helps

okay so all i can give is advice based on what i've learned so far my daughter was also exposed to similar content at a cousins house and it seriously caused some issues i learned i can't stop what she's going to be exposed to when i'm not around i have to trust her to make the right choice and stop it or redirect or if need be get an adult also you can disable all chat from roblox this way she can at least play the games my social media policy with her is that i have access to all her accounts until she is to make sure she is safe not to snoop or read private conversation she is now and is old enough to meet age restrictions on several apps now she's chosen not to get them i think in part because i dont she's more family oriented right now than peer so i'm lucky in that sense she does have chatting apps i monitor but be nosey but not secretive ask her what she's doing and how the game works who her friend are and what's going on with them tell them about your friends age appropriately of course how you feel about things create an open dialog make sure she knows she can come to you always even if she pushes you'll still be standing there i think chat shouldn't be restricted but she should feel like if a friends conversation raises red flags go to mom mom can help she knows i am monitoring her accounts for her safety at this point i'd like to think she doesn't mind because she'll even ask me what i thought about something someone said in a chat or ask me to go look to get my opinion

i need help with how to approach my daughter f i f let my daughter f play roblox because i thought it was safe don’t come at me i literally saw it and thought “kids game” well i installed bark on her phone which is essentially a parental app to keep tabs on your kids to make sure she’s being safe today i saw some things on the app that seemed a little weird so i checked the laptop and she was still signed in so i took a peek she has been pretending to be a boy talking to another boy about having sex with him she doesn’t know i know but i really want to have a talk about it with her and don’t know how to approach it so here i am…asking reddit does anyone have any advice on how to go about talking with her about this and the dangers of chatting online and also lying to people about who she is i’m just lost and do not know how to approach the conversation without the classic pre teen shutting down because of awkward conversation how do i tell her i found the conversation how do i keep her safe 😞

there are a couple different really important issues here number one is the chatting with strangers your daughter now knows exactly how easy it is to pretend to be someone she’s not but i doubt she has considered how easily she could be fooled by someone pretending to be a child as well in fact that could be what’s happening right now so out of a ton of concern i would approach this situation very carefully but firmly as soon as possible i have personally let my kids know this is the biggest concern and they are never to give out their names town school name etc and that if anyone is ever threatening them even with real information they weren’t supposed to give out that they can come to us no matter what we’ve explicitly explained the types of threats predators and scammers might use so that hopefully they can recognize that and still come to us i’ve described in detail how they can threaten to hurt your family how they can offer to take you away for awhile of your parents are hounding you etc all the things in my opinion knowledge is power here and i often do it in the car where they have to listen and can’t go away does she know about bark and we’re there any rules put in place where she knew you could look at her devices at any time i would be honest and concerned but try to avoid showing anger i think i would avoid any punishments at this time although moving screen time to a common room might be a suggestion

you can tell her you learned the game has a chat feature which isn’t safe for kids explain why without ever letting her know you saw her chats i think reading her chat makes sense—you needed to see if she had sent anything that could put her in danger however she will see it as a violation of privacy just let her know you saw online that it has features that aren’t safe for her if there’s a way to disable that feature and let her still play great you could use gender inclusive language in the future to help her feel safe opening up to you example “is there anyone you want to go to the dance with ” instead of “are there any boys you want to go to the dance with ”

let’s take this from the perspective of the daughter yo curious likely recognizes that this is not an approved line of conversation if i was and told not to do something online i would more than likely get better at hiding it which is exactly what i did when i was in my opinion it needs to be a non judgmental conversation entirely only informative and protective how you tell her you know about the conversation is entirely up to you however the conversation needs to be had in a very real tone vs hypothetical if it’s hypothetical she may not even relate it to what you’re trying to talk about if this is the type of conversation my parents had with me at i feel i would have been far more receptive and likely would have found myself in a lot less trouble than i did *while in the car like another commenter suggested so she can’t walk away when she gets uncomfortable* “hey my daughter i was doing some reading on some of the dangers of the internet and i wanted to chat with you about it” … *the pause is important* … “one thing that kept reoccurring in the dangers for young ladies your age is online sex talk it’s not that the talk is bad or wrong it’s that the other person is anonymous i heard that old men *like * be dramatic keep it light hearted will pretend to be the same age as the girls playing the game and convince them to start an online relationship that’s not so bad for the young ladies but then when they both trust each other these old men will start asking for pictures one story i read about was the old man talked with the young girls for over a year to build her trust and get these photos… did you know that’s illegal for him to have these photos… makes me want to throw up just thinking about it… ” still very jokingly not blaming not saying this is the wrong thing for her to do just emphasize how it’s not safe and you have no idea where things will end up another thing with these online predators that’s you may or may not want to educate your daughter on is that the predators may use these photos to blackmail her into more photos different “acts” and even meeting in person once they have these photos they will use them in anyway that gets her to do what they want in this day and age it’s extremely likely she’s going to send nudes to someone at some point in time the absolute best you can do is assure her that you’re a safe person to talk to if those photos end up in the wrong hands it could even be her first boyfriend’s friend group and if that happens she should know she can talk to her to help her through it

i have been in this same situation before and the stance i took on it was that yes many of us did very similar things when we were younger but the internet is a much different and much more dangerous place now that it ever was back then my thoughts and i explained this to my child are that if they are grown enough to be talking and acting this way they are definitely grown enough to talk to me about it and learn the very real life risks and dangers of what they are doing we then had a conversation about how amazing the internet has potential to be but it’s my job to keep them safe from an ever growing atrocities that can come from being online and explained they are not old enough or have the mental or emotional capacity or be informed enough at their age to choose the safest things for themselves yet i did go into detail about the things that can happen and have real life examples because as i said if they think they are grown enough to be doing these things they’re grown enough to hear what has happened in the past i know it sounds very harsh but it is the only thing that has truly worked

as someone who dealt with self harm when they were younger completely taking away something she likes is not the answer i would first look at her edits & make sure they are appropriate then you can monitor her account from your own account i’m pretty sure youtube doesn’t allow comments on minor accounts anymore but there was an outrage about it so maybe they went back so i would look at that but either way there is definitely a compromise to be had this was something she did & made her happy before she started it would be extremely unfair to take that away completely that’s how you make her think you’re punishing her for going through whatever she’s going through

your very lucky she asked permission and didn't just start doing it and how you proceed from here you should tell her how proud you are of her asking if you do decide to let her be on the platform you should have full access to the account to delete comments disable comments until she is teach her about anonymity of the internet and how it allows people to say things they wouldn't otherwise say in person you need to be prepared to guide her and if it requires more of your time then so be it but also if the mental health crisis was directly related to the social media aspect of these edits then i would have a hard time letting her continue your not going to be able to cover her indefinitely from assholes on the internet but slowly you can build up her confidence so that the effects of bullies is minimalized good luck with whatever decision you do decide to make

i think it’s time to have a frank and honest discussion about internet safety and how to develop her own healthy boundaries when i was her age i made a myspace profile and my mom found it i had some age inappropriate stuff on there but my mom didn’t freak out she and i sat down at the computer together while i navigated through the site and explained to me why certain pictures were not smart to put online on a public profile asked how i felt about some language friends were using in chats etc her approach worked—i felt like i could trust her and followed her guidance because she laid it out in a way that made sense for my whole adolescence i felt ok going to her if i saw something online that made me feel uncomfortable

as far as i know discord is one of the more normal ones for teens and tweens to use my wife even uses it for her video game stuff i am not into video games so i do not know much about it; but she uses it daily to connect with her people the same way i used facebook messenger back in my teens

discord is just a social platform it's like a chat server banning discord though fine if that's what you want to do won't really solve your problem she is determined to chat online with people's she knows and people she probably doesn't know she will find another forum to chat on

not a parent but i was a kid who grew up with mostly unrestricted internet access i also use discord pretty much daily this is a tough one because the more you push the better she will get at hiding it from you i would know i got really good at hiding that kind of stuff from my mom however you should know that it's against discord's terms of service to be below the age of on their platform so she likely had to lie about her age to even make an account i think you first and foremost should find out exactly who she's talking to especially those that you don't recognize does she know them from school or online does she know how old they are are they sending her inappropriate messages that aren't just jokes or memes also does she have a cellphone if discord's on her laptop it's likely on her phone too as far as punishment trying to scare her out of doing it likely won't work there should be consequences for lying but also i understand the appeal of having a discord server for a group of friends with a shared interest that in itself should be fine as long as it's kept appropriate and from your description it looks like it hasn't been again not a parent but honestly if she's just engaging in the one server and you are worried about the content of it i'd ask to join the server so you can see the conversations and content being posted in real time if it's not kept appropriate or she makes another server to avoid you being in it then i'd go ahead and take it away completely is not old enough for unsupervised internet usage take it from someone who was that age and talking to the wrong crowd online and has many regrets regarding that edit also if you have any questions about discord i'd be happy to answer

if your teen daughter shares dirty jokes swears and looks at risqué pictures in a chat with her friends she is probably doing the same things in person if that is all i was doing online at that age my mother would have been proud this all sounds like normal behavior of someone becoming a young adult have a convo with her about online stranger danger and what she should share with people she does not know but aside from that as long as she is not getting into trouble let her be herself with her friends maybe ask that she limit her conversations to people she knows irl

we have a very tech savvy year old ever since he started playing games minecraft and roblox he's been more interested in finding out exploits hacks glitches and in general the world outside of the game itself we had some superficial website blockers that he managed to circumvent with ease i never thought we'd be playing a game of cat and mouse with such a young child over internet safety but he's just that smart we ultimately had to drop the hammer down and lock up everything using microsofts family app be cautious though because if you leave your account open they can use it to app permissions to theirs so i also make sure my pc has a short sleep timer now he has to ask us for digital permission to use sites apps etc of course continue to monitor their use and teach them online saftey if your kid is interested in tech set her up for success and ignore well meaning parents that try to discourage you from encouraging them tech is a valid hobby and career path just the same as any other and as long as we take measures to keep them safe we can mitigate the risks

my kid has had his own cheap ish chromebook for a few years as he needed it for virtual st grade in he has access to his school account and a monitored personal account via google family he's now in th grade and loves to use scratch to do fun coding projects makes pixel art with a free app and makes google slides projects with his friends as long as it's monitored via google family bark sitting with them etc i think having a computer for kids is a great idea gets them used to how to use a pc when so many only grow up learning tablets and phones

computer can should only be used in a public place before beginning with programming you should teach the yo about computers and digital citizenship i’m currently using [typingclub] for digital citizenship and typing lessons then computer lessons on miacademy google also has a free digital citizenship game but i think typing club has much more to offer and is also free so digital citizenship is important because it teaches kids the importance of internet safety our children need to understand *why* we aren’t allowing to access the internet without being monitored they also need to understand why we need to be safe online and not share any personal information and how to be safe online but as child gets older we can remove some of the restrictions when it’s age appropriate my child has their own firefox browser that they use on the ipad as well on the ipad i can block specific urls like google youtube bing i can also change the settings so only websites that i added to an approved list can be visited so if it’s not on the approved list then it be blocked on both computer and ipad i can set the default search engine to a kid safe search engine which we’re currently using [kiddle] it redirects any searches to searching on the kiddle search engine and provides very limited results that are safe for kids kiddle also has their own encyclopedia wiki page with additional information and facts and images as well on the computer i added extensions to block sites but it’s a shared computer in our living room so everyone can use it and my husband and i have our own browser profile and the kids have a profile for them kids aren’t allowed to use the computer without our supervision mostly because they don’t know how yet and it’s being used mostly only to teach them how to use computers and for online learning block websites and search engines you don’t want them to use apparently microsoft has a kids mode idk i have to check it out a kids mode sounds great tbh but here’s an [article on gadget mates] that goes through how to make firefox kid friendly

use [qustodio] free for one device upgrade to subscription for premium features more devices has time limits per app settings exclude include certain web categories exclude specific url’s monitor it all this is best because even if she connects to another wifi network the device is still locked down vs just router parental controls i wouldn’t give her access to things like google images social media etc also make sure obviously to make her the standard user not admin because then it’s possible to remove qustodio get around it as per the device itself i can speak from my own experience got my own computer when i was to learn programming it helped me quite a bit to learn the basics and get pretty comfortable would recommend [scratch] for someone her age just starting out it’s very gamified block level programming once she’s mastered that i would recommend [khanacademy programming] goes from basic to pretty advanced from there if you have a library card and your library supports it you can get free access to [linkedin learning] which has tons of courses that are super well made from beginner to advanced on basically any programming technology topic

since my spouse is a software engineer and we're both enthusiastic pc gamers we decided to bring our small human in to the tech echo system with his own pc before his own tablet phone we have our pcs all in our family office guest room so we're more able to monitor his usage plus it's less isolating than him sitting alone with a tiny screen inches from his face off in his own room we can see what he's doing we play games together or alone together sometimes etc think family lan party plus since he sees us working with computers and first helped us build ours and then actually built his with us he's developing an understanding for the 'behind the scenes' aspects of tech and media consumption we have parental controls on each element he has his own google account which is under ours and set as a minor we set it up and have the passwords his pc is password and pin locked with restrictions on when he can use it and for how long same with gaming services we've got his own accounts for things when allowable that we are the password account owners for and we curate them he has limited child accounts on our streaming services and we keep apprised of what he's engaging with obviously nothing is perfect for a while we were playing cat and mouse with him because he started getting up early and turning on the playstation to watch netflix and then to play so we had to add passwords so he started using the xbox so we had to add more passwords and then he started sneaking the switch and and and i expect we'll go through growth adjustment course corrections as he gets older he doesn't have access to youtube or social media at all yet and we won't be introducing it for years we both have sm but we don't share his photos and only sparingly post about him so he can decide the level his online presence when he's older we also make a point to engage each other and him over media we're using talking about it sharing etc so he is seeing us have a hopefully healthy relationship with it

okay so it looks like minecraft and roblox are two entirely different yet somewhat similar things * **minecraft** is a multiplayer game for pc android devices and consoles where players harvest resources and use them to create items and structures of varying complexity focus is on playful exploration and creativity with some mild social elements * **roblox** is an online game creation suite slash multiplayer environment best described as if unreal engine and second life had a child with a moderate to severe learning disability [see here] both seem harmless that said all online interactions your kids have need to be strictly supervised much like burning man is an awesome place where there's tons of cool shit to see and experience but you still wouldn't just let your kid run around completely unsupervised kids also should never go online without an adult paying close attention to what they're doing

caught my son searching adult content i need some advice i f have a son m who loves youtube & roblox we have a computer that we'd put in his room because it was the best place to put in our house due to a lack of space he's also allowed to use my husband's phone to play roblox with his sister we do limit screentime & the computer has some intense parental controls but my husband's phone doesn't have these because it's his phone however my husband was going through his phone a while back & saw some p*rnographic pictures on there that he'd not saved there was also a very inappropriate video posted onto my husband's youtube account that had gotten flagged & taken down it had a video of woman in the background & my son face fully exposed in the foreground singing some youtube meme song we went through the phone & the computer & discovered that somehow our son had managed to turn off the parental controls & was searching p*rn we cleared the history so we could tell if he did it again reinstated parental controls & had a talk with him every talk has been met with extreme emotions he's on the autism spectrum & has always dealt with intense emotions we have to take breaks in discussions to calm him down before we can continue so this conversation was met with a ton of tears even some yelling and insisting it wasn't him all he does is sob & yell that he didn't do it we know for a fact that it was him it couldn't have been literally anyone else we even caught him in the act because we'd wanted to make sure we weren't misplacing the blame we figured out that when he wanted to search something up he'd shut his door & try to be very quiet turn down the volume everything he could to be inconspicuous but since his doorknob broke months ago & we haven't bothered to replace it yet we can still see into his room & caught him red handed i need to know what else i can do the computer has been removed from his room & the only way he's allowed on my husband's phone is when he's supervised & playing roblox with his sister we also figured out that my husband's phone has a kids mode that will keep him from searching things he shouldn't my biggest concern is what's made him want to look this stuff up he's never been exposed to any of this as far as we know we're very careful about not exposing our kids to adult things literally the only time he's not supervised by us is when he's with my parents who are even more strict than we are & when he's on the bus for school our only theory is that he's hearing things he shouldn't on the bus because he for some reason despite being a tiny year old gets placed in the back of the bus where all of the highschool kids sit he hates sitting back there these kids have been bad influences before & helped him get into trouble he's fully responsible for his behavior but peer pressure is pretty rough i'm sorry i know i'm rambling i just need some advice on what to do here

what are the cool but safe online games for < year old my yo son is very interested in roblox minecraft clash of clans etc but after trying these things there’s two things i’m concerned about * predatory micro transactions the slot machine nature of some these games is difficult to manage as a kid it’s hard to understand why we shouldn’t just buy of gems * chat the ability to connect with strangers and freeform chat is a concern family members have spoken about some very purile talk all the way to very suspicious predatory behaviour with their kids i’m at a bit of a loss to find something cool that is popular that allows him to start experience online fun any suggestions

with minecraft you just need to not play online it can be a pain to find a good server to play on and honestly i think public servers will be full of jerks i play on a private server one of my friends hosts if your kid and his friends all want to play minecraft you could look into getting them their own private server it doesn't cost too much and if all the parents of kids who want to play chip in it will cost almosy nothing a month

my year old plays roblox we have precautions in place but he also likes this site called abcya com you can't talk to other people on there or play with them so the social aspect isn't there if that's what he's looking for in roblox we have set up his account so no one can message him every time he wants to play a new title we check it over first most games have pretty strict rules about acceptable behavior and in my experience mods are pretty good about getting rid of those who can't follow the rules there is a running chat during most games that shows up in the corner of the screen but you can hide it bad or even suspect words are blocked with hashtags only once while watching the chat did i see someone say something racist and i was happy to see the other players jump all over that person and they were reported and removed from the game we haven't had any problems with roblox but we also keep up on what he's playing and don't allow him to privately message people or anything we check his account every few days you can spend money on roblox but without your credit card he can't and there's plenty to play and do without paying for it i don't know as much about minecraft but our local library has their own server kids can play while there or can access from home and it's tightly controlled behavior wise you might see if your library has something similar

you have to start talking to your kid about microtransactions **now** i'm not kidding you need to warn them that there are tricks built into the game to make them spend real money and would have very real consequences advise them that if they are ever caught intentionally doing microtransactions they are forbidden from playing video games until they're old enough to understand why tell them that there have been children who racked up hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt in accidents from some of these games additionally as far as chat is concerned it can be turned off of most games most games that allow children under the age of don't have verbal chat or have a very restricted type chat have a conversation with your child about how people online talk to each other let them know not only that there are people who can be rude but there are also people trying to trick him online too best to go ahead and work in any conversations about bullying or long distance communication that you need to at this point these are all conversations you need to have before your child goes online if you listen to this advice though they'll be fine if you try to only find games to work around this problem instead of just having the conversation with them enforcing it you're going to regret it source i did this with my kid when he was he's now and he's fine and has never accidentally bought a game or a microtransaction be aware of what your kids are doing be familiar with the games they are playing be ready to answer questions as they come up and you will never have the problems you were worried about

my kids are we play a lot of minecraft online and not and we also play roblox they get the ideas of what video games to try out based on what they hear from schoolmates and what they see on popular youtube channels of other gamers we have some boundaries first off their screens can be seen from my desk i don't make a deal out of looking at what is happening on their screens but if i see something that border on inappropriate i make a subtle suggestion hey that looks like something an adult might watch and they know to change channels or do something else i know i cannot stop them looking at inappropriate stuff i can only guide them; if they want to be naughty or sneaky it can happen anywhere at school a friends house the library computers my approach is to guide but be open to questions and support at all times the do get friend requests but we've already had the talk about how only people they have met in real life can be accepted as virtual friends i also point out that virtual micro transactions are worthless and the stuff you buy can be played for they do get steam vouchers occasionally and i tell them to spend wisely or lose out i usually select their games or guide their choices and they have a good idea already of what is 'adult content' versus what is 'kid appropriate' something else you might run into soon email confirmations for games and distributions eventually you will get tired of having your youtube channel filled up with roblox promo content and you will have a hard time registering your username and your kid's usernames on the same email address for some titles or services yep they have to have an email address of their own at some point i made a domain for my family and i manage the email i have it mirrored to my inbox and i can see what is coming and going before they do to reduce the spam overhead i chose a domain name that is uncommon and i do the registering of products to be sure the check boxes for 'send more stuff' are not set in the future minecraft will have it's own currency system i understand this move it to compensate plug in and map developers better you can check out the r minecraft sub for updates and a better explanation i go there often for build ideas or resource pack announcements there is a sub r mcservers in which you can search for family oriented minecraft servers or you can just make your own it's not too difficult

also ask in personalfinance personally i’d suggest monetizing it but be very careful is she anonymous if so take steps to improve anonymity never mention name location school city etc ensure her account is not easily traceable etc if not anonymous it’s not a deal breaker but be careful even more important is mentally this is probably something that is short term will stop making money in months or a year it is extremely important for you to embrace that and not push her to continue it or blame her once the viewers and money falls off let her keep being a child financially set up a account at fidelity or similar the account is in your name with her as beneficiary she can spend it on college tuition room and board computers also trade school private school it can also be used to fund her roth ira up to k invest in a target date fund for the year she turns inside the roth ira if she earns more than some amount for example years of expenses at a state university allowing for growth above that invest in a different account

online friends facing serious issues what to do i have two tween daughters that are among the millions of kids online playing roblox and such they are very well educated on online safety and have been very guarded with respect to who they talk to chat with etc there are lots of posts about the dangers to my kids but that’s not the point of this post the problem i am presenting some these online friends have a lot of serious issues safety issues like potentially abuse kids not having a safe home or in other cases talking about suicide it really impacts my kids’ overall mental state at times i don’t think i can cut them off from the internet world and i feel like they are safe from predators i monitor things closely but i am not sure how to handle this i don’t want them to ghost someone in need and i appreciate their empathy they show to others but i think they can quite quickly descend into a feeling of helplessness for these “friends” and their issues in at least one occasion the group of internet friends were trying to figure out how to contact suicide prevention for a person do we shield them from these realities do we guide them that there is a line that should be held between real friends on online “friends”

there is a reality between real friends and online friends that's true at any age the obvious difference is that you truly never know who's on the other side of the keyboard i think it's great that your kids are caring people i think you can't completely shield them and having a script to go to is helpful ultimately giving them the guide between real and online friends is necessary the truth is that there are probably some kids that are venting and need help and there are others that don't they may be older they may be making things up the truth is usually somewhere in the middle but your kids are way too young to be tasked with the responsibility of other kids safety mental health and well being

dear lord you are being obtuse roblox serves as a gaming and social platform boundaries are necessary but year olds that is ten twelve year olds in shitty situations aren't toxic or energy vampires for sharing their issues with their friends

i would be looking at this from a different angle i grew up in the dawning era of the internet when open chat was entirely the norm most of the games i was playing when i was your daughter's age had completely open chat your daughter will likely continue to play these games whether you want her to or not the only thing that will change if you forbid ones with open chat is that she will get better at hiding those ones from you video games are a socialization tool for modern kids especially now in the age of covid this is where her friends are which may or may not be the same ones she has at school and this is how they hang out the absolute best thing you can do with her is to teach her proper netiquette help her learn how to spot threats and predators explain to her what information is ok to share what music she likes what her hobbies are etc and what information is not ok to share her age where she lives what school she goes to her e mail address or social media etc make sure she knows how to use the block and report functions of any game she is playing make sure she knows not to send or accept any files that someone sends her and and this is the important step that i think far too many parents skip because of how uncomfortable it can be to talk about explain why explain how there are scammers out there who want to mine her for information so they can potentially get access to her or your accounts and financial information or get a virus onto her machine explain how there are predators out there who want to hurt her or coax her into sending them pictures of her naked give her the grim details because it will help contextualize why the rules that you're setting exist kids generally understand rules if you explain out the reasons behind them and will react better to those than blanket bans

gamer dad here i grew up in the environment that is influencing your son right now explain what is wrong and why it is wrong throw in an explanation of what you felt when you saw this monitor his activities he's not old enough to navigate the complex social interactions on the internet on his own you need to have full insight into what he says in which settings get a keylogger in a worst case scenario it's either monitored internet or no internet strict end time for internet usage your router can most likely restrict when his devices can connect to the internet leverage it if he's on a windows computer use the parental controls from microsoft to monitor app game usage browsing history and more monitor youtube activity review some videos there's so much garbage you need to know what he watches to get what cultural frame he is in disallow channels if necessary cooperation with his friends parents will be important if your kid says stuff like this he's probably surrounded by others who also say similar things you've gotta fix the problem in all ends or it'll just come back

your child being homeschooled adds an interesting element to this my knee jerk reaction is to take away his online privileges if you were to do that you'd be taking away so much more than just online privileges you would essentially be socially cutting him off unless there are irl friends he has this fact has me thinking that you should only use this as a last resort maybe use this as a boundary if the behavior continues honestly though the behavior is pretty normal around that age group is it gross yes absolutely have a talk with him sit down and discuss how the things he's saying are offensive how it makes you feel and that you don't want him broadcasting that type of energy then you can wrap up the conversation with if i see this again your privileges will be revoked this way you can clearly establish what your expectations are and what happens if he fails to meet those expectations it's not a threat it's a metaphorical line in the sand

i definitely would not get him a ps first of all they’re incredibly expensive to get for a kid if you or another adult in your household had one already and let the kids play it only under supervision that would be different but i would never buy one just for a child it’s also very definitively an adult oriented console the majority of the games available are not appropriate for kids and younger teens anything that is will be available on another platform and they notably do not have parental controls so you’d have to lock it away and supervise them while they play to make sure they’re not playing inappropriate games or are talking to strangers it’s *so easy* to talk to strangers on the ps online multiplayer is default turned on for a lot of games and the mic and speaker are built into the controller and since there aren’t parental controls you have no way to restrict that other than physically sitting there with them you seem very on top of your children’s online safety so i don’t need to tell you how dangerous that is for kids switch and xbox are better they’re far cheaper have parental controls and have a lot more age appropriate games the cross platform thing is a different story contrary to what some other people said out of those sports games fifa is the only one that’s cross compatible from ps and only with the xbox if you have a windows pc it’s also cross compatible with that so you wouldn’t even need a console if he wanted to play with his friends if i was you and if i had a pc i’d start there let him try fifa with his friends for a few months to test the waters maybe he’ll lose interest and you’re only out the cost of the game maybe he likes it but you notice it’s having negative effects in which case you’ll be able to stop it earlier and easier maybe he likes it and is able to regulate himself and use it responsibly at which point the topic of a console can be revisited emotional regulation at his age is definitely something to consider the number of kids i know who have rage smashed a switch or a controller is ridiculous so i would want to be sure my child could handle it before giving them something expensive to break
it's probably better than a tablet and much better than a smartphone in terms of not screwing up kids i mean

the switch lets you set limits on how long and how late the console can be played you can have either an alarm pop up or have the game force stop but you can adjust or override it from your phone with an app if you want to you can also whitelist games so only content you approve can be played you can prevent online chat and photo sharing as well the xbox has nearly the same the time controls are similar it’s also app based and you can set it up to require your approval to download a game or to add a friend with the xbox they can send a push notification to your phone to request more time but you can do it manually too [here is the switch game library ] [here is the xbox game library ] personally i think the switch is more kid friendly the xbox has games like gta cod resident evil etc which imo far far too many children and teens play given the content you can restrict what they’re allowed to buy of course but that temptation of “it’s right there if i could juuuuust steal mom’s phone for a second” will still be there most of the kid friendly content on xbox is multiplayer sports legos and minecraft the switch does also have gta cod etc **but** the balance of adult games to kid games is much better the switch has zelda games even the og ones if you subscribe pokémon animal crossing mario smash bros mario kart lego minecraft kirby and a lot more popular ones the switch does have fifa but you can only do online multiplayer with other switches not with xbox or ps or anything else tldr; parental controls are comparable between the two and you control them with an app on your phone the switch has more age appropriate games as well as games he can grow into the switch is also portable and good for car trips you can buy kids protective bumper cases for it the switch doesn’t have as many sports games as xbox and the switch doesn’t support cross console play

that’s a tough one ill say as a minecraft player that it’s very hit or miss what actually happens on a server some servers keep themselves clean others allow more vulgar behavior im not well versed in child psychology but if he’s already willing to talk to you you can probably show interest and get him going on about it enough that he’d reveal undesirable things without thinking too much about it also doesn’t hurt to ask him what the server’s name is and give it a quick google many servers have websites that list out their rules and all of that good opportunity to be reinforcing how to be safe and sane on the internet it’s a very valuable skill that could very well be helped by being ‘in it’ within reason

my almost year old also loves minecraft and i just recently started letting him play online he plays on the hypixel server which has a lot of rules to try to create a safe environment i’ve popped in and watched over his shoulder here and there and haven’t seen or heard anything inappropriate so far at one point he was also wanting to play “among us” and “fortnite” but i vetoed those mainly based on the fact that my high school students were playing those a lot at the time and i know what kind of language they use unfortunately he has a chromebook for school and so he has access to a lot of free to play browser based games that i’m not always around to supervise so far he has found some kind of fortnite esque game seems to be pretty limited though so probably not nearly as popular as well as a gaming called taming io which so far seems to be ok he’s even talked his little sister into playing that one with him occasionally i’d say watch him play or even play with him for awhile get a feel for the game or server to see if it’s appropriate if a game offers a way to turn off chat features that’s a great thing to take advantage of and talk to him about things he may encounter that you might not approve of for instance i expect my kids not to curse but i do occasionally and my mother swears like a sailor but they know those are words for adults and they shouldn’t use them

pulled from common sense media “roblox doesn't specify a minimum age users of any age can create and join groups chat and interact with others such an open approach can pose some risks to kids especially younger ones and though roblox has some safety precautions in place it remains a target for people with less than good intentions still because of the learning potential roblox offers common sense media rates it ok for users age + help your kids protect themselves by enabling privacy settings and teaching them how to be safe online ” in a nutshell i think roblox is a bit too old for a five year old if you are looking for age appropriate alternatives i really liked pbs org’s free games for kids they are age appropriate educational help teach strategy and are good starting blocks for little ones my five year old really enjoys the sesame street ones maybe check those out

managing screen time for multiple kids many devices i am desperately in search of a comprehensive solution for managing and limiting children’s screen time across a variety of devices i often feel like the kids spend way too much time on their phones tablets family laptops etc ￼￼ one is a macbook and the others are windows it is hard to manually track all this and because there are multiple kids it’s a nightmare an ideal solution would let me allocate daily screen time per kid and also define maximum length usage sessions on the more in demand devices the devices would have to know which kid is signed in to help track usages and enforce limits an added bonus would be a way to define max usage limits on specific apps like roblox or youtube i have tons of creative software for them to explore but they get sucked into low quality repetitive garbage on roblox way too easily i’m hoping some techie parents out there have discovered solutions for this especially ones that work across platforms like windows mac and ios even better if it also works for gaming consoles and kindle fire tablets but i realize there must be limits to what is possible ￼on closed platforms like those￼ any help or insight would be much appreciated thanks ￼
